bookinfo.subtitle: control the damage before the damage controls you

preface.title: What is DamageControl
preface.para: DamageControl is a continous integration system that helps you to keep feedback about build failures. If you are working on a project that is supervised by DamageControl and one of your team members commits changes to the Software Configuration Management System, DamageControl will detect the changes to the codebase and attempt to build a integration build of your project.

If this integration build succeeds, everything is OK. The green light shows up and you can continue your work. If the recent changes have broken the build, your project is damaged. DamageControl helps you to control the damage before the damage controls you. The first step is that the team members who have broken the build are informed. There are different ways to do it, they can receive an EMail, an instant message, an issue could be filed in the issue tracker or a status monitor at their desktop could show a red light.
In the next step, the objected changes could be rolled back, so that the project is in an consistant state again. The damager will repair the damage and everyone else will continue to work.
What distinguishes DamageControl from other continuous integration systems like CruiseControl or CruiseControl.NET?

listitem.para: DamageControl is under heavy development. If you want to use something rock solid and do not care for the newest features, stop reading here.
DamageControl is platform agnostic. You can build your project with Java, Ant, Ruby, .NET, Nant, Make or whatever tools you like.
DamageControl is easy to use and offers simple, web-based configuration. No need to edit XML files.
DamageControl is self-contained. It comes with an own runtime and an embedded webserver.
DamageControl has many channels to notify users of successful or failed builds. And it is very easy to create your own notification channel.
DamageControl supports as many projects as you need and your build server can handle. It is even possible to run multiple builds at once.
DamageControl builds are triggered by CVS or Subversion on every commit. It can install the triggers for you and supports polling, if it is impossible to use triggers.
DamageControl integrates with tools like ViewCVS or Fisheye as well as Jira, Bugzilla and Scarab.

preface.para: In this documentation you will find everything needed for running and configuring DamageControl. Additionally you will find information important if you would like to implement extensions to DamageControl to make it fit your specific needs.

Before you decide that you do not need a program like DamageControl, because it does not help you to create more shiny new code in shorter time, consider the advantages of detecting problems early: The sooner a problem is detected, the cheaper it is to fix it.

If you identify problems during requirements engineering, you can talk with the customer and the problem is gone. If you identify problems during the design phase, you have all opportunities to find a design that will avoid those problems. If you occur problems during the implementation, you can still fix bugs and create workarounds for other issues. Trying to correct a problem in an already deployed system is very hard and expensive.
So DamageControl helps you to identify problems early, to solve identified problems and to produce high-quality-software cost-efficient while keeping your schedules.

section.title: Linux, UNIX, Mac OS X
section.para: To install DamageControl on a server with an UNIX-like operating system, follow these steps.

step.para: Download Ruby, version 1.8.2_pre2 or later from the Ruby Homepage. In most cases it is not required to install Ruby manually, as most Linux distributions have prepared packages of Ruby available, which can be installed using the distribution's packet manager.
Install a client for the SCM system you are using on the build server. Supported version control systems are currently:

listitem.para: the Concurrent Versioning System (CVS)

step.para: Download DamageControl from the DamagControl download page. There is one distribution tarball for every successful build and in most cases the latets build is the best choice.
Unpack the tarball to a directory of your choice. Define a environment variable DAMAGECONTROL_HOME which points to the directory where you unpacked the archive.

section.para: Additionally it could be useful to install an Apache Web Server to allow configuration of access privileges, a Mail server to send notification messages per EMail, or an IRC server.

If you are using mail notifications, the optimal way to inform your developers is using a mailing list. Everyone who is subscribed to the mailing list will receive the notification, but DamageControl can still send mails to individual developers.

section.para: DamageControl can be installed by typing emerge damagecontrol on the command line. If you would like to use HTTP authentification, you should have the use-flag apache2 set.

section.title: Windows
section.para: Users of the Microsoft Windows Operating System can install DamageControl using the installer. You do not need to download a separate Ruby runtime, as it is included in the installer.

section.title: Configuring the DamageControl Server
section.para: Users of DamageControl under Microsoft Windows can start DamageControl using the created entries in the Start menu. On other platforms, starting DAMAGECONTROL_HOME/bin/damagecontrol is the preferred solution. This script expects a configuration file as command line argument.

caution.para: It is very dangerous to run DamageControl as root-user. It is better to create a new user, which has read and write access to DAMAGECONTROL_HOME and DAMAGECONTROL_WORK, but cannot access other user's files.

section.para: A default configuration is provided in the file DAMAGECONTROL_HOME/bin/server.rb. If you would like to make changes to the configuration, you should create a copy of server.rb and edit and use this configuration file.
The following sections cover example configurations for a number of purposes. All these configurations are optional and not needed if you just want to test DamageControl.

section.title: Access Control
section.para: By default everyone can access the DamageControl server and add projects or change configurations. This is not useful if you want to have an public build server, because you do not want to allow strangers to change the configuration of your DamageControl server.

This configuration involves two steps. Firstly you have to configure DamageControl to allow connections only from the local machine. Secondly you have to create a Apache proxy server that will serve the DamageControl pages.
To modify the DamageControl configuration follow these steps.

step.para: Open your DamageControl server configuration file in a text editor.
Find the section which configures the network server. This section looks in the default configuration like this:
step.programlisting: server = DamageControlServer.new( :RootDir => ENV["DAMAGECONTROL_WORK"], :HttpPort => 4712, :PollingInterval => 60 # specified in seconds # to allow access only from localhost then uncomment line below # (when running behind an Apache proxy for example) #:AllowIPs => [ "127.0.0.1" ], )

step.para: Change the lines to this configuration to allow access only from the local machine. If your webserver is running on a different machine, you should replace 127.0.0.1 with the IP-address of the remote webserver.

section.para: In order to serve the DamageControl pages from an ordinary web server, install a web server and configure it to work as a proxy for DamageControl. An example configuration for the Apache webserver is like this.
section.programlisting: ProxyRequests off RewriteEngine On ProxyPass /public http://localhost:4712/public ProxyPassReverse /public http://localhost:4712/public ProxyPass /private http://localhost:4712/private ProxyPassReverse /private http://localhost:4712/private
section.para: This configuration passes all requests to http://servername/public and http://servername/private to the corresponding locations of the DamageControl server. To add authentification to the private configuration parts, you should append following lines to the Apache configuration.
section.programlisting: <Location /private> AuthName "DamageControl" AuthType Basic AuthUserFile /etc/apache2/dc.passwd Require valid-user </Location>
section.para: No user will be able to access the web configuration interface of the DamageControl server, unless the user has provided a username-password-configuration that is included in the password file /etc/apache2/dc.passwd.

section.title: Configuring DamageControl Projects
section.para: If you have installed DamageControl and set up DamageControl to fit your needs, it is time to configure projects DamageControl will build. This is very easy as you can use the web interface for almost all tasks.

section.title: Creating Projects
section.para: In order to create a new project, open the private dashboard of the DamageControl server. If DamageControl is running on your local machine, the URL is usually http://localhost:4712/private/dashboard, if DamageControl is running behind an Apache proxy, open http://hostname/private/dashboard.
A new project is created by following the New project hyperlink. The following page allows you to enter the project name, the build command and some other configuration options.
After having entered all configuration options, you can click the Save button and the new project is created.

You can navigate to the project overview using the Back to project hyperlink or the hyperlinked project name in the navigation breadcrumbs. From this location, which is generally available at http://hostname:port/private/project/projectname. This page allows you to clone the project, which will create a project with identical settings, but different name, to configure the project, to trigger a new build, even if no changes have been made to the codebase and to clean all working files.

On the public project page, which is available at http://hostname:port/public/project/projectname you can just view the current build status, inspect the command line output of the build or view unit test results. Aditionally it is possible to view the working files and the history of occurred builds.

section.title: DamageControl and Build Tools
section.para: DamageControl will support any build tool you need in your project. All you need to do is to enter the relevant build command in the field labeled Build command. If the command returns an exit code of 0, the build is successful, if the build end with another status code, it was a failed build.

section.title: DamageControl and SCM Systems
section.para: DamageControl has an event-view to your project. This means, rebuilds are triggered when a change to the codebase of your project (an event) occurs. To make this triggering possible, your software configuration management system must support triggers.

For SCM systems like CVS and Subversion, DamageControl can install triggers automatically if it has local access to the repository. To use a specific SCM, you will have to select the radio box for this SCM and enter the required configuration parameters.

If you have local access to the repository, there will be a new action available at the private project webpage, which allows you to create the repository and to install the triggers. If you are less fortunate, you will have to install the triggers yourself, which is described in the following sections.

section.para: DamageControl offers a convenient way to view the results of the last builds of a project. If you use a RSS reader like NetNewsWire, RSSBandit, Straw or the LiveBookmarks fetaure of Mozilla Firefox, you should locate the orange XML icon at the project page and subscribe to the linked RSS-feed.
Each time a build succeeds or fails, you will be notified through your RSS reader.

section.title: Windows System Tray
section.para: Another nice way to be notified is the Windows System Tray icon, which can be installed for DamageControl. You can configure a number of projects on different DamageControl servers and the tray icon will notify you of successful or failed builds through popup ballons and sounds.

The installation of the Windows System Tray icon is done through the installer package. After starting the tray icon, you should click it with the right mouse button to enter the settings menu and configure the projects to monitor.

section.title: GNOME System Tray
section.para: There is also a System Tray Icon for the GNOME desktop, which will show a red or green status light if depending on the build status of your monitored projects. The GNOME System Tray Icon currently does not support the display of notification messages nor the playing of sound to notify the user of finished builds.

To use this icon, you will need a Linux computer with following software: Mono, Gtk# and the GNOME desktop. After unpacking the DamageControl-MonoTray package, you can start the Tray Icon using following command.

section.title: Getting Support
section.para: The best way to contact the developers of DamageControl is though the DamageControl-Users-Mailinglist. You can subscribe to this mailing list by sending an empty EMail to user-subscribe@damagecontrol.codehaus.org.
Sometimes you might find other users or developers in the DamageControl IRC channel (#damagecontrol) at irc.codehaus.org.

question.para: Why do I get random crashes?

answer.para: There is a bug in the YAML implementation in Ruby 1.8.1 which makes DamageControl crash a couple of times every day. Usually something like the following is displayed in the log and in the console output:

screen.computeroutput: /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/yaml.rb:39: [BUG] rb_gc_mark(): unknown data type 0x14(0x4023e51c) non object ruby 1.8.1 (2004-05-02) [i686-linux-gnu]

answer.para: Installing Ruby 1.8.2 solves the problem (it is currently in preview3 but should be released soon).

question.para: How does DamageControl detect a failed build?

answer.para: DamageControl has absolutely no knowledge of what the build command it executes actually does. It just launches the command you tell it to launch. (Could be notepad.exe or gimp for that matter - try it!). Since the build command is an arbitrary command, there might not even be any (system err/system out) output from it, so DamageControl doesn't try to parse that output. (Although it pipes it to a log file which you can browse to from the web admin).

What DamageControl does is quite old fashioned (yet a well-established paradigm, at least in UNIX land): It looks at the return code from the build command. If it's 0 it is OK, otherwise it is KO. In short this means that your build command (whatever it is) must make sure to return a non-0 return code in the event of a build failure. Ant, Maven and Make do that.

If you are writing a your build script in shell-script or some other scripting languages like Python and Ruby you need to make sure you are exiting with a non-zero exit code on build failure. Have a look at ant.bat to see how to do it from a .bat script.
For example, the DamageControl build scripts (written in ruby and which of course are built in DamageControl itself) have code that looks something like this:
answer.programlisting:
def fail(message = $?.to_s) puts "BUILD FAILED: #{message}" exit!(1) # <------ non-zero exit code, build failed! end
def run(args) begin # … snip, run the build ... rescue Exception => e fail(e.message) end puts "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" # exits with exit code zero end
answer.para: Under UNIX, the exit status of a shell script is the same as the last command run, which is generally what you want.
Under Windows, you may have to add exit errorlevel to the end of your batch file.

question.para: How do I pin certain builds to certain executors?

answer.para: DamageControl has the ability (see DC-240) to have builds 'pinned' to certain executors. This means that each build can control which executors will, or won't, be allowed to execute it.

formalpara.title: Why would I want to pin a build?
formalpara.para: Well there's a number of ways this would be useful, but for example in our scenario we have 8 or 9 functional test builds that must be run in serial (ie FTest A, FTest B, FTest C etc). The advantage to having multiple executors allows us to reduce the average time for each build. However if the problem is that if we have a set of serial builds like this we can no longer have multiple executors because we can't guarantee they won't start to parallel each other. Pinning all these builds to a single executor means that they will run in serial, but won't block the entire build queue.

chapter.title: Developer Handbook
chapter.para: This chapter contains information for developers of DamageControl or users of DamageControl who would like to extend the features offered by DamageControl.

section.title: Development Environment
section.para: Development of DamageControl requires the Ruby runtime, a CVS client and some developer packages like crypt. If you are workon on a UNIX- or Linux-machine, you can install the programs via the operating system's package manager. Users of Microsoft Windows should install cygwin.

If you would like to create installers for Microsoft Windows, you should install the Nullsoft Scriptable Installation System. It is possible to run makensis on Linux, if you compile it yourself or install NSIS under Wine.

section.title: Getting the Source
section.para: In order to get the latest source code, you should checkout the module damagecontrol from the CVS repository at codehaus.
You will find the source code for the server in the directory server, the directory client contains the source code for the various DamageControl client programs.

Developers use different connection settings to access the DamageControl CVS repository. You will have to use CVS via SSH, which should be no problem, as Public Key Authentification is already set up for all CodeHaus developers.

textobject.para: This object diagram describes in coarse detail how some of the core objects relate to each other. It describes how a build process starts by first checking out, determining if there are any changes, and then possibly executing a build.

step.title: A checkout is requested
step.para: There are two different stituations that will result in a build to be executed. They both start with the blue objects.

listitem.para: A build is triggered (step 0). This can be done via the web interface or over XML-RPC. Typical XML-RPC invocations come from either a trigger in the SCM (if it is installed), or via some other external program using the XML-RPC-interface.
The SCMPoller decides it is time to poll a project and see if there are any changes.

step.title: The SCM checks out latest
step.para: The CheckoutManager asks the SCM to check out the latest code. This call will return a ChangeSets object which contains detailed information of what was checked out (and maybe even deleted) since the last checkout. It then finds most recent timestamp of all the changes in the ChangeSets and saves that timestamp in the project configuration (to be used in the future).

note.para: For practical reasons, if the checkout is a first-time-checkout, the SCM will return the timestamp of the most recent checkin rather than all the changesets. This is to avoid having a too big list of changes in the first build report.

step.title: A build is requested
step.para: A build object is created (which holds the changesets), and the execution of that build is requested within the BuildScheduler.

note.title: Special Note for SCMPoller
note.para: This will only happen if there were changes. If there were no changes as the result of the checkout, no request will be made with the BuildScheduler.

step.title: A build is executed
step.para:
When a BuildExecutor becomes available
There may be several of them, depending on how you have configured DamageControl. See . , the scheduled build will be given to it. The BuildExecutor will execute the build, and finally send an event on the hub when the build is finnished (wether it succeeded or not). This event will then be picked up by other components, which may perform various notification tasks (EMail, IRC, etc.).

section.title: Introduction
section.para: DamageControl features a powerful XML-RPC API that allows developers to create various clients for DamageControl.

Some operations of the API should be open for all. This includes all operations that do not modify any state on the DamageControl system, but merely provide querying functionality. These operations are part of the public API and marked with the modifier keyword public in the following synopes. The endpoint for the public API is http://host:port/public/xmlrpc.

Other operations should be restricted to administrators or project developers. These are operations that modify the DamageControl system's state or execute builds on the server. The endpoint for this API is http://host:port/public/xmlrpc and access to it is usually authenticated. The following synopses will mark these functions as private.

note.title: Why XML-RPC and not insert favourite RPC technology here?

listitem.para: It is platform neutral, and clients can be written for many platforms.
It is simpler than e.g. SOAP.
The XML-RPC library for Ruby is excellent.

note.para: We are consigering to also support SOAP, but we have not found an easy and clean way of doing this in Ruby. If you really need SOAP, let us know.

Minute of the hour as 2-digit number with trailing zero, e.g. 02
Second as 2-digit number with trailing zero, e.g. 06

section.title: SCM Extensions
section.para: This is a guide for people who want to write a new SCM plugin for DamageControl.

section.title: Introduction
section.para:
DamageControl relies on the RubySCM
Ruby SCMM is an API that has been factored out of DamageControl's core). API for interaction with underlying SCMs.

The first step in adding support for a new SCM is to write a Ruby SCM class. To prove compliance with the RubySCM API we have written a test suite that you can use. If your class passes that test suite, you can be pretty sure your SCM class is good enough for DamageControl and we will happily add it to the codebase.

Run the test again. Assuming your code is correct, you should now get a different error, which should lead you to implement the next method. Just continue like this until all tests are passing.

If your SCM's command line interface writes output that needs to be parsed, we recommend you to implement the parsing logic in a separate class. That will allow you to test the parser without running the command.

section.title: Web Interface
section.para: If you write your own SCM plugin you would probably also want the DamageControl web admin to display it as a supported SCM in the project configuration pages. Every SCM has its own set of values that needs to be specified in order to check out code.
To enable your SCM to be configured from the web you need to implement something we call an SCMWebConfigurator. See CVSWebConfigurator for an example on how to implement one.

Basically you need to create an erb file for the part of the form that is the SCM configuration. This will be included into configure.erb. You can also define JavaScript code that will be included in the top of the same page and you can execute JavaScript code on the onLoad event. The details of all this should become quite apparent by reading the code for the above mentioned CVSWebConfigurator.

To inform the DamageControl server about your new SCM you edit DamageControlServer.scm_configurator_classes in DamageControlServer.rb. You can also override this method in your own server configuration if you like.

section.title: How to contribute
section.para: If you contribute all of this with unit tests (see the SVNTest.rb and SVNLogParserTest.rb for inspiration) you will earn lots of DamageControl points. If you know how to write working code, but not how to write unit tests, we'd of course be happy to accept your contribution regardless.

note.title: If you do not know Ruby
note.para: f all of this is too big a task for you you can still contribute. The DaamageControl development team doesn't have acces to every single SCM out there. But we'd be able to implement this for you if you help us out with some extra information such as:

listitem.para: What are the command line commands for executing checkouts, updates and getting (history) logs?
What does the output of the log command typically look like?

note.para: Please contact us on dev@damagecontrol.codehaus.org for further information.

question.para: Why do I get a weird error from REXML?

answer.para: Sometimes you get an error like this:

screen.computeroutput: 1) Error: test_successful_build_data(DamageControl::CruiseControlLogParserTest): NameError: undefined local variable or method `num' for REXML::Encoding:Module c:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.8/rexml/encodings/ISO-8859-1.rb:13 c:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.8/rexml/encoding.rb:29:in `load' c:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.8/rexml/encoding.rb:29:in `encoding=' c:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.8/rexml/source.rb:41:in `encoding=' c:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.8/rexml/parsers/baseparser.rb:183:in `pull' c:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.8/rexml/parsers/pullparser.rb:45:in `pull' ./damagecontrol/cruisecontrol/CruiseControlLogParser.rb:40:in `parse_top_level' ./damagecontrol/cruisecontrol/CruiseControlLogParser.rb:27:in `parse' ./damagecontrol/cruisecontrol/CruiseControlLogParser.rb:25:in `open' ./damagecontrol/cruisecontrol/CruiseControlLogParser.rb:25:in `parse' damagecontrol/cruisecontrol/CruiseControlLogParserTest.rb:14:in `test_successful_build_data'

answer.para: This is because the REXML distributed with certain versions of Ruby is pretty crappy. So DamageControl includes its own REXML version but in order to have the included version override the version distributed with Ruby you need to specify the switch -I<damagecontrol home>/server (or -I. if you are in that directory) when starting the test-suite or the server.

question.para: Why do I get weird problems with libraries?

answer.para: This could be because you have specified a relative path in the library path ('.' for example, as in ruby -I. script.rb) and have changed the working directory somewhere in the script. There are basically one workaround and one solution to this problem, the workaround is simply to specify an absolute path instead of the relative path. The solution is to use the with_working_dir method (in the FileUtils module) instead of changing the directory with Dir.chdir, the with_working_dir restores the previous working directory before it exits. Like this:
answer.programlisting:
require 'damagecontrol/util/FileUtils' include FileUtils
with_working_dir("somedirectory") do # … trut your stuff ... end
